summary: James R. Schlesinger is mentioned in three documents. One document is a memorandum from James Angleton to Secretary of Defense James Schlesinger analyzing Soviet policy towards the United States based on information from a former KGB member. Another document is an inventory of Rockefeller Commission files, which details the contents and file codes of documents related to the CIA's activities and the Kennedy assassination. The third document discusses questionable activities involving both the CIA and FBI, which are under review by the Senate Select Committee (SSC).
significance: James R. Schlesinger's significance in the JFK context is indirect. He is mentioned as the Secretary of Defense receiving a memorandum analyzing Soviet policy, and his name appears in an inventory of Rockefeller Commission files related to the Kennedy assassination. This suggests he was in a position to be informed about relevant intelligence matters, but the documents do not directly implicate him in any specific actions related to the assassination itself.
